1: This is a classic public goods game. Since there are two players and contributions are multiplied by 1.6, each point I contribute generates 1.6 points total, with 0.8 points coming back to me and 0.8 going to my opponent. This means contributing is individually costly (I lose 0.2 points per contribution) but collectively beneficial. In the first round, I'll contribute a moderate amount to signal cooperation and test how my opponent responds, while not being overly generous in case they free-ride.
